channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Happened on Day 82 of the War in Ukraine
item.description: Hundreds of Ukrainian fighters were taken by bus to Russian-controlled territory. Ukraine’s president said the combat mission in the city was over, capping some of the longest, fiercest resistance of the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel complex in the southern port city of Mariupol on Sunday. More than 250 Ukrainian fighters, some severely wounded, were evacuated on Monday.

item.title: Russia Planned a Major Military Overhaul. Ukraine Shows the Result.
item.description: Russia wanted to build a leaner, more flexible fighting force and eliminate waste, bureaucracy and corruption. But entrenched, Soviet-era practices endure.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Justyna Mielnikiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian soldier on an armored vehicle in the Georgian town of Igoeti in 2008.

item.title: In Rebirth for NATO, Europe Unites in Face of Putin’s Ambition
item.description: Sweden’s and Finland’s embrace of NATO after decades of neutrality is a clear statement that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has ended an era of European illusions about Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swedish soldiers marching in Stockholm earlier this month.

item.title: How the Long Recovery From Bush Fires Could Decide Australia’s Election
item.description: The fires that tore through the country in late 2019 and early 2020 are history, but halting recovery efforts have kept memories vivid and anger fresh.
item.dc:creator: Kieran Pender and Matthew Abbott

item.title: Estonia’s Tough Voice on Ukraine Urges No Compromise With Putin
item.description: Kaja Kallas, the prime minister, remembers the repression of life under Soviet rule and sees the same brutality in occupied Ukraine, which she believes is fighting for all of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kaja Kallas of Estonia in Brussels just after Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

item.title: The War in Ukraine Could Empower Qatar
item.description: As the United States and Europe seek to deprive Russia of its oil and gas income, their leaders hope Qatar can help fill the void.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gas flares at a port at Ras Laffan, Qatar’s principal site for the production of liquefied natural gas, around 50 miles north of the capital, Doha.

item.title: Élisabeth Borne Is Named as French Prime Minister
item.description: Élisabeth Borne, the minister of labor who previously was in charge of the environment, will be the second woman to hold the post in France.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Labor Minister Élisabeth Borne of France at the Élysée presidential palace in Paris this month at the investiture ceremony of President Emmanuel Macron.

item.title: Johnson’s Softer Tone on Northern Ireland Trade Rules Belies Hard-Line Plans
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who traveled to Northern Ireland on Monday, also urged a power-sharing government in the wake of Sinn Fein’s victory in legislative elections.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Mr. Johnson is also facing pressure from the Biden administration, which has warned him not to take any steps that could jeopardize the Good Friday Agreement.

item.title: How Australia Saved Thousands of Lives While Covid Killed a Million Americans
item.description: The United States and Australia share similar demographics, but their pandemic death rates point to very different cultures of trust.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Southbank promenade in Melbourne, Australia, in March.

item.title: German Conservatives Win State Election in Setback for Scholz
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s Social Democrats scored record-low votes in the first major electoral test he has faced since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The top candidate of the Christian Democratic Union in North Rhine-Westphalia, Hendrik Wüst, arrived at a polling station Sunday with his family.

item.title: In South Korea, ‘Ghost Surgeries’ Lead to Cameras in Hospitals
item.description: After scandals in which doctors let unsupervised assistants operate on patients, the country is becoming one of the first to require cameras in operating rooms.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kookmin Hospital, near Seoul, voluntarily put cameras in its operating rooms in 2020. A new law will make them mandatory nationwide.

item.title: A Mini-Russia Gets Squeezed by War
item.description: The self-declared republic of Transnistria, on the Ukraine border, has been steered by Moscow for decades. During a rare visit, a reporter and photographer get an inside look into how it operates, and hear from Transnistrians their fears of war.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Cristian Movila
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times

item.title: Sanctions Shed Light on Putin’s Private Life
item.description: As Western nations place sanctions on people close to the Russian leader, including family members, the strict secrecy surrounding his private life is being punctured.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

item.title: As Sri Lanka Plunges Into Ruin, the Rajapaksa Family Is on the Run
item.description: Once empowered by triumphant ethnic nationalism after a brutal civil war, the Rajapaksa dynasty has been undone by what its own allies call incompetence and denial.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Skandha Gunasekara
item.media:description: From left, Mahinda Rajapaksa, Gotabaya Rajapaksa and Basil Rajapaksa in 2018. The family has dominated Sri Lanka for the better part of two decades.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: An apparent Russian victory in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel complex in the southern port city of Mariupol on Sunday.

item.title: Michael Bloomberg Plans a $242 Million Investment in Clean Energy
item.description: The billionaire and former mayor of New York City will fund programs in 10 developing countries.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired power station in Metsimaholo, South Africa, about 65 miles south of Johannesburg. The country is one of 10 targeted in Michael R. Bloomberg’s initiative.

item.title: Biden Administration Lifting Some Trump-Era Restrictions on Cuba
item.description: The changes include an expansion of flights to the country and the restarting of a family reunification program.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: A traveler at the airport in Havana in March. The Biden administration has relaxed some restrictions after a lengthy review of Cuba policy.

item.title: Ukraine Signals End of Bitter Battle at Azovstal Steel Plant
item.description: More than 250 fighters were evacuated from the besieged Azovstal complex, after holding out and sheltering civilians for weeks under near-constant Russian bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A wounded Ukrainian service member from the besieged Azovstal steel factory in Mariupol is transported under the escort of the pro-Russian military in Novoazovsk on Monday.

item.title: Further Russian Retreat Seen in East Ukraine, Another Setback for Putin
item.description: Russia appeared to shrink its already narrowed goals to take the Donbas region, as NATO and its two newest applicants, Sweden and Finland, practiced war games near Russia’s border.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski, Rick Gladstone and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A complex in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday, that was damaged by Russian bombardment.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia’s Faltering Campaign
item.description: Plus climate’s role in Australia’s upcoming election and a Covid-19 protest at Peking University.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Russia sought to create a leaner, meaner military. But entrenched, Soviet-era practices endure.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Justyna Mielnikiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian soldier on a tank in the Georgian town of Igoeti in 2008.

item.title: Biden Approves Plan to Redeploy Several Hundred Ground Forces Into Somalia
item.description: The president also signed off on targeting about a dozen Shabab leaders in the war-torn country, from which Donald J. Trump largely withdrew in his final weeks in office.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Somali soldier patrolling near the presidential palace after a car bombing in Mogadishu, the capital, in September. The Biden administration’s goal in Somalia is to try to reduce the threat from Shabab terrorists.

item.title: How Often Can You Be Infected With the Coronavirus?
item.description: The spread of the Omicron variant has given scientists an unsettling answer: repeatedly, sometimes within months.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing site in San Diego last year. Earlier in the pandemic, experts thought that immunity from vaccination or previous infection would forestall reinfections, but Omicron has changed that.

item.title: Putin’s New Problems
item.description: An update on the second phase of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops in the frontline town of Barinkove.

item.title: An Intimate Look at Mexico’s Indigenous Seri People
item.description: The identity of the Seri is integrally tied to their natural environment, which in recent years has been susceptible to an increasing number of existential threats.
item.dc:creator: Núria López Torres
item.media:description: Lydia, the shaman of the Punta Chueca community, sings a traditional Seri song.

item.title: Treasury Secretary Yellen Looks to Get Global Tax Deal Back on Track
item.description: The Treasury secretary is traveling to Warsaw, Brussels and Bonn, Germany, this week at an uncertain time for the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Liz Alderman
item.category: House Committee on Ways and Means
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen is expected to press Poland to adopt a global tax deal that was agreed to last year by more than 130 countries looking to end corporate tax havens.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: NATO to fast-track Nordic applications to join.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in a heavily bombed neighborhood of Kharkiv on Sunday.

item.title: Pandit Shiv Kumar Sharma, Master of the Santoor, Dies at 84
item.description: He single-handedly elevated a 100-string instrument little known outside Kashmir into a prominent component of Hindustani classical music.
item.dc:creator: Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
item.media:credit: Prasad Gori/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Pandit Shiv Kumar Sharma performing on the santoor in 2009 in Pune, India. “My story is different from that of other classical musicians,” he once said. “While they had to prove their mettle, their talent, their caliber, I had to prove the worth of my instrument.”

item.title: NATO Leaders Say They Will Speed Finland and Sweden Membership Bids
item.description: In another setback for Moscow, top officials from alliance nations met over the weekend in Berlin to discuss admitting Finland and Sweden and supporting Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swedish forces training this week on Gotland IsIand.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: North Korea’s Growing Outbreak
item.description: Plus India bans most wheat exports and South Korea amends surgery laws.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, chided health officials for “incompetence” at a Saturday meeting, according to state media.

item.title: Katsumoto Saotome, Who Preserved Stories of Tokyo Firebombing, Dies at 90
item.description: He compiled six books of survivors’ recollections of the 1945 attack. He also founded (without government support) a memorial museum.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Katsumoto Saotome in his home in Tokyo in 2020. He spent more than half a century amassing the stories of people who had survived the 1945 firebombing of the city.

item.title: Sweden’s Governing Party Says It Will Vote to Join NATO
item.description: The announcement was a shift for the Social Democratic Party, which has supported Swedish neutrality since before the collapse of the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christina Anderson
item.media:description: Sweden’s prime minister, Magdalena Andersson, giving a press conference after a meeting at the ruling Social Democrat’s headquarters in Stockholm on Sunday.

item.title: Pro-Russian Bloggers React to Reported Donets Military Disaster
item.description: As the news of the losses at the river crossing started to spread, some Russian bloggers did not hold back in their criticism of what they said was incompetent leadership.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Marc Santora

item.title: Finland Launches Bid to Join NATO, Declaring a ‘New Era’
item.description: The Nordic nation would end decades of nonalignment if, as widely expected, it is admitted to the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Finland’s Prime Minister Sanna Marin, left, and President Sauli Niinisto at a press conference at the Presidential Palace in Helsinki, on Sunday.

item.title: Mass Shooting in Buffalo
item.description: A massacre at a Buffalo supermarket was the deadliest in the U.S. this year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People hug at the scene of a mass shooting at a supermarket on Saturday in Buffalo, N.Y

item.title: After Lebanon’s Collapse, Can an Election Fix the Country?
item.description: On Sunday, Lebanese voters got their first chance to pass judgment on lawmakers since the economy fell apart. Few expect things to improve.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Asmaa al-Omar
item.media:description: Lining up to vote in Beirut, Lebanon, on Sunday.

item.title: Somalia Elects New President, but Terrorists Hold True Power
item.description: The militants of Al Shabab collect taxes, decide court cases and control the streets. Somalis ask, will a new government even matter?
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Malin Fezehai
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tensions were high in the Somali capital ahead of Sunday’s presidential election.

item.title: Turkey Offers to Evacuate Mariupol Fighters Despite Disagreements
item.description: Turkey has had a ship waiting for weeks in Istanbul to evacuate those remaining in the Azovstal steel plant, but Ukraine and Russia have not agreed to a plan, a Turkish official said.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Smoke rising from the Azovstal plant in Mariupol on Friday.

item.title: As Eyes Are on Eurovision, Europe Has Another Song Contest
item.description: The Liet International, a competition for minority and regional languages, lacks the glitz of Eurovision. But its organizers say it helps keep endangered tongues alive.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Klaus Bo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Billy Fumey, of France, singing in the Franco-Provençal language at the Liet International song contest in Tonder, Denmark, on Friday.

item.title: For Putin, a Nordic Nightmare Is Springing to Life
item.description: With Finland and Sweden likely to request NATO membership, and Ukraine counterattacking in the east, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is facing more setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier walking past a bombed-out warehouse where Russian troops were based until last week in a village north of Kharkiv on Saturday.

item.title: Mohammed Bin Zayed Becomes U.A.E. President
item.description: Sheikh Mohammed has used his small country’s oil wealth to exert great influence across the Middle East and in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, center, on Saturday was unanimously elected president of the United Arab Emirates by the Federal Supreme Council.

item.title: In London, a Long-Awaited High-Tech Train Is Ready to Roll
item.description: The Elizabeth line, 13 years in the making, will soon uncoil under central London with cathedral-like stations and roomy cars. Its managers say it’s a testament to the power of public transportation.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: What to Do This Weekend
item.description: Fill your cultural calendar with Pulitzer winners, piano bars and 24 ways to make eggs.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: From Streets to Rallies, Truckers and Supporters Weigh Conservative Candidates
item.description: In his bid for the Conservative Party leadership Pierre Poilievre is wooing supporters of the blockade that shut down Ottawa and closed border points.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Pierre Poilievre, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservative Party, frequently invokes the rhetoric of February’s protesters.

item.title: India Bans Most Wheat Exports, Adding to Fears of Global Food Insecurity
item.description: The ban could compound a worldwide shortfall worsened by the war in Ukraine and exacerbate an already dire forecast for global hunger.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Unloading wheat grain at a wholesale market near Amritsar, India, last month.

item.title: In Afghanistan, Collecting Scrap Metal Is a Risky Pursuit
item.description: Discarded metal left by decades of conflict has become a livelihood for impoverished Afghans. But many have been killed by unexploded munitions.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Safiullah Padshah and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers in Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, sorting through scrap metal for dangerous items before it is sent off to the Khan Steel Mill.

item.title: New Delhi Fire Leaves Dozens Dead
item.description: Officials said that at least 27 people had been killed, most of them assembly line workers, and that the toll could rise.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar
item.media:description: At the scene of the fire in New Delhi on Saturday. The four-story building housed a number of manufacturing operations.

item.title: At a German Hideaway, Oligarch Villas Challenge a ‘Silent Contract’
item.description: Tegernsee, a luxury getaway in Bavaria, is known for quietly hosting the superrich. But war in Ukraine has divided locals about whether the authorities should go after the assets of their wealthy Russian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: An American Moment in an Australian Campaign
item.description: To some analysts, a spat over transition surgery looks like something from an overseas culture war.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison dismissed criticism of the Liberal candidate Katherine Deves as cancel culture.

item.title: North Korea Says Its Covid Outbreak Is Spreading Fast
item.description: State media reported 21 new deaths and a huge jump in suspected cases on Saturday, but it was unclear how many had been definitively linked to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, chided health officials for “incompetence” and “irresponsibility” at a meeting on Saturday, according to state media.

item.title: Amid War, Ukraine Is Favored to Win Eurovision Song Contest
item.description: The exclusion of Russia from the contest has underlined the country’s estrangement from the west, including in popular culture.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kalush Orchestra, Ukraine’s representatives in the Eurovision Song Contest, performed a rousing performance of the song “Stefania” during the contest’s semifinals on Tuesday in Turn, Italy.

item.title: New Zealand’s Jacinda Ardern Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: The prime minister’s rules kept transmission at bay for two years, and by the time the highly infectious Omicron variant hit, the vast majority of New Zealand’s population had been vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand in Parliament in March, announcing the easing of some of the country’s pandemic restrictions.

item.title: Protests Triggered by Rising Food Prices Spread in Iran
item.description: “They have no hope, they have no trust in the government and they can’t tolerate the status quo any more,” one Iran expert said of the protesters in at least six provinces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: An Iranian man walks with his shopping bags in Tehran on Friday. The Iranian government increased the price of basic food items such as cooking oil, chicken, eggs and dairy products drastically this week.

item.title: West Increases Pressure on Putin, Including Sanctions on Reputed Girlfriend
item.description: The Russian leader was challenged by the prospect of an enlarged NATO, plans to get Ukrainian grain exports past a Kremlin blockade, and sanctions on his purported mistress.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Mark Landler and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers towing a Russian armored vehicle from a bombed out bridge in the village of Rus’ka Lozova, 15 miles north of Kharkiv, on Friday.

item.title: Israeli Police Attack Mourners Before Funeral for Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: As hundreds gathered to witness the start of Shireen Abu Akleh’s funeral procession, riot police assaulted the people carrying her coffin.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli security forces attacking mourners carrying the coffin of the reporter Shireen Abu Akleh on Friday.

item.title: Treasury Warns Foreign Banks Against Helping Russia Evade Sanctions
item.description: Adewale Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, met privately with international financial institutions to make clear the consequences of sanctions evasion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Emily Flitter
item.media:description: Adewale Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, in Washington last month. “If you provide material support to a sanctioned individual or a sanctioned entity, we can extend our sanctions regime to you and use our tools to go after you as well,” he said in an interview on Friday.

item.title: Robert C. McFarlane, Top Reagan Aide in Iran-Contra Affair, Dies at 84
item.description: As national security adviser, he pleaded guilty in an illegal scheme to aid Nicaraguan rebels in the 1980s. Guilt-ridden, he attempted suicide.
item.dc:creator: Neil A. Lewis
item.media:description: Robert C. McFarlane testifying at the Iran-contra hearings in May 1987. A former Marine, he distinguished himself in the aftermath of the scandal by his full and unequivocal acceptance of blame for his actions.

item.title: Germany Identifies Far-Right Extremists Working in Security Services
item.description: The report reflects an effort by the authorities to come to grips with a long-running problem following several scandals involving members of the far right.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police in Dresden in January. Germany’s interior ministry released a report Friday on extremists in the country’s security services.
